description: From Middle English crak, crake, from Old Norse kráka (“crow”), from Proto-Germanic *krak-, *kra- (“to croak, caw”), from Proto-Indo-European *gerh₂-, itself onomatopoeic.

entries.meaning: Any of several birds of the family Rallidae that have short bills.

verbs.description: crake (third-person singular simple present crakes, present participle craking, simple past and past participle craked)

entries.meaning: To cry out harshly and loudly, like a crake.

description: From Middle English craken, from Old English cracian, from Proto-West Germanic *krakōn, from Proto-Germanic *krakōną.
Cognate with Saterland Frisian kroakje, West Frisian kreakje, Dutch kraken, Low German kraken, French craquer (< Germanic), German krachen.

verbs.description: crake (third-person singular simple present crakes, present participle craking, simple past and past participle craked)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To boast; to speak loudly and boastfully.
